bestBHT.bht: John's baptism was the seal of his ministry and mission, representing his authority. When Jesus asked about the source of John's baptism, it suggested a link between John's authority and his own preaching and miracles. This new ordinance required authorization either from God or from men. The baptism of John held great significance, symbolizing a profound connection to Jesus' own work and highlighting its importance within the broader story of their ministries.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: ministry and mission, of which baptism was the seal.
John Gill: This was a new ordinance, and John must have his authority for administering it either from God, or from men.
Christ is desirous to know from which he derived it in their opinion; suggesting, that by the same authority John, his forerunner, came baptizing, he himself came preaching and working miracles.
He himself came preaching and working miracles.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse speaks of the baptism of John, emphasizing its importance in his ministry and mission. It was a significant action, symbolizing the seal of his authority. Jesus, in asking about the source of John's authority to baptize, implies that his own preaching and miracles were carried out through the same divine authority. The baptism of John was a new ordinance that required authorization either from God or from men. Overall, this verse highlights the pivotal role of baptism in John's ministry and how it connects to Jesus' own work.

The baptism of John was an integral part of his ministry and mission, serving as a seal of his authority. Jesus, by questioning the source of John's baptism, suggests a parallel between John's authority and his own preaching and miracles. This new ordinance required authorization either from God or from men. The baptism of John symbolized an important connection to Jesus' own work, emphasizing the significance of this act in the larger narrative of their ministries.
